title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as SEC. 30B. Private Land Conservation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows eligible farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the amount that would be allowed as a deduction for a qualified conservation contribution. The credit is subject to a maximum limit of $360,000 for any taxable year, with special rules for joint returns. The tax credit for eligible farmers and ranchers is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year and is divided equally between spouses. All members of the same controlled group of corporations are treated as one taxpayer. The credit cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits or the tentative minimum tax for the year. Eligibility for the credit is based on being an eligible farmer or rancher. The tax credit for eligible farmers and ranchers is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year and is divided equally between spouses. Eligibility is based on being an eligible farmer or rancher, defined as having 60% or more gross income from farming. Special rules include an irrevocable election for application. The tax credit for eligible farmers and ranchers is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year and is divided equally between spouses. An irrevocable election is required for application, and no deduction is allowed under section 170 for a qualified conservation contribution if the taxpayer elects the credit instead. Excess credit can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The amendments in Sec. 30B apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. It treats qualified farmers or ranchers as individuals for conservation contributions. SEC. 4 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easements. SEC. 4 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easements, effective for estates of decedents dying after the enactment of this Act.
